Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Ocean-Ice-Atmosphere Interactions in the Terra Nova Bay Polynya, Antarctica
Award.AbstractNarration:
Antarctic coastal polynas are, at the same time, sea-ice free sites and 'sea-ice factories'. They are open water surface locations where water mass transformation and densification occurs, and where atmospheric exchanges with the deep ocean circulation are established. Various models of the formation and persistence of these productive and diverse ocean ecosystems are hampered by the relative lack of in situ meteorological and physical oceanographic observations, especially during the inhospitable conditions of their formation and activity during the polar night.


Characterization of the lower atmosphere properties, air-sea surface heat fluxes and corresponding ocean hydrographic profiles of Antarctic polynyas, especially during strong wind events, is sought for a more detailed understanding of the role of polynyas in the production of latent-heat type sea ice and the formation, through sea ice brine rejection, of dense ocean bottom waters

A key technological innovation in this work continues to be the use of instrumented unmanned aircraft systems (UAS), to enable the persistent and safe observation of the interaction of light and strong katabatic wind fields, and mesocale cyclones in the Terra Nova Bay (Victoria Land, Antarctica) polynya waters during late winter and early summer time frames.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Antarctic plays a critical role in the global climate system and thus impacts all of society. This project used unmanned aerial systems (UASs) or drones to observe the temperature, humidity, pressure, and winds in the Antarctic atmosphere. These UAS observations allowed us to explore fundamental processes related to the way the Antarctic atmosphere interacts with the ocean and sea ice surrounding the continent. Our research focused on an area of open water surrounded by sea ice, known as polynyas, where large amounts of heat and moisture from the ocean can enter the atmosphere. This large energy and moisture exchange results in the formation sea ice and the creation of very dense ocean water, known as Antarctic bottom water. This dense seawater helps drive global ocean circulation. The heat and moisture removed from the ocean also alters the atmospheric state and can lead to the formation of small, intense storms known as polar lows. These storms are an important source of snowfall over the Antarctic continent.

Our work on this project helped demonstrate the utility of small UAS for conducting scientific research in the Antarctic. While inappropriate use of drones has received much negative attention we found that UASs can also provide high quality data at a much lower cost than traditional manned research flights, thus offering the potential for cost savings for future Antarctic (and beyond) research.

An important part of all scientific research is communicating your findings to other scientists, and we have done this this by attending scientific meetings and conferences and publishing our results in peer reviewed scientific journals. Equally important is providing the public with information about our scientific activities. We have achieved this goal through the maintenance of a blog describing Antarctic field science, by visiting, either in person or online, students in elementary schools and at a community college. We have also contributed a chapter on Antarctic weather and climate to a book on Antarctic science targeted at the general public.
